Definition: You will be given four sentences of a story. Your job is to select an end sentence from (A) and (B) such that the story sounds incomplete and incoherent.

Positive Examples.input:
Sentence1: Rick grew up in a troubled household. Sentence2: He never found good support in family, and turned to gangs. Sentence3: It wasn't long before Rick got shot in a robbery. Sentence4: The incident caused him to turn a new leaf. 
 (A) He is happy now. (B) He joined a gang.
Positive Examples.explanation: As mentioned in fourth sentence, the incident turned a new leaf to Rick's life; so, he must be happy now. Also, he was previously in gang, so, this incident cannot make him to join a gang. So, B is incorrect.

Positive Examples.input:
Sentence1: Laverne needs to prepare something for her friend's party. Sentence2: She decides to bake a batch of brownies. Sentence3: She chooses a recipe and follows it closely. Sentence4: Laverne tests one of the brownies to make sure it is delicious. 
 (A) The brownies are so delicious Laverne eats two of them. (B) Laverne doesn't go to her friend's party.
Positive Examples.explanation: As mentioned in the third sentence, Laverne follows the recipe closely; brownies should be delicious and she should not cancel going to her friend's party. So, B is incorrect.

Positive Examples.input:
Sentence1: Sarah had been dreaming of visiting Europe for years. Sentence2: She had finally saved enough for the trip. Sentence3: She landed in Spain and traveled east across the continent. Sentence4: She didn't like how different everything was. 
 (A) Sarah then decided to move to Europe. (B) Sarah decided that she preferred her home over Europe.
Positive Examples.explanation: As mentioned in fourth sentence, Sarah didn't like that everything was different in Europe; she must have preferred her home over Europe. So, A is incorrect.

Negative Examples.input:
Sentence1: Rick grew up in a troubled household. Sentence2: He never found good support in family, and turned to gangs. Sentence3: It wasn't long before Rick got shot in a robbery. Sentence4: The incident caused him to turn a new leaf. 
 (A) He is happy now. (B) He joined a gang.
Negative Examples.explanation: As mentioned in fourth sentence, the incident turned a new leaf to Rick's life; so, he must be happy now. However, A is correct answer, not incorrect.

Negative Examples.input:
Sentence1: Laverne needs to prepare something for her friend's party. Sentence2: She decides to bake a batch of brownies. Sentence3: She chooses a recipe and follows it closely. Sentence4: Laverne tests one of the brownies to make sure it is delicious. 
 (A) The brownies are so delicious Laverne eats two of them. (B) Laverne doesn't go to her friend's party.
Negative Examples.explanation: As mentioned in the third sentence, Laverne follows the recipe closely; brownies should be delicious. However, A is correct answer, not incorrect.

Negative Examples.input:
Sentence1: Sarah had been dreaming of visiting Europe for years. Sentence2: She had finally saved enough for the trip. Sentence3: She landed in Spain and traveled east across the continent. Sentence4: She didn't like how different everything was. 
 (A) Sarah then decided to move to Europe. (B) Sarah decided that she preferred her home over Europe.
Negative Examples.explanation: As mentioned in fourth sentence, Sarah didn't like that everything was different in Europe; she must have preferred her home over Europe. However, B is correct answer, not incorrect.

Instances.input:
Sentence1: I always try to go to bed on time. Sentence2: Last night I was hooked watching a new tv show. Sentence3: Before I knew it it was really late. Sentence4: I should have been asleep hours ago. 
 (A) The television show had hooked me in. (B) I hated the television show.

Sentence1: It was autumn. Sentence2: Todd's yard was full of leaves. Sentence3: He decided he needed to rake them all up. Sentence4: Once he was done, he put them all in a bag. 
 (A) Todd put them out in the trash. (B) Todd opened up the bag and spread the leaves around.

Sentence1: Everyone told Matt he ate too much red meat. Sentence2: He ignored all their warnings about red meat and health problems. Sentence3: One day after a juicy burger, Matt had a heart attack. Sentence4: Matt became a vegetarian after he left the hospital. 
 (A) He stayed heart attack free for the rest of his life. (B) Matt celebrated leaving the hospital with a large steak.

Sentence1: I remember the scariest haunted house I've ever been to. Sentence2: It was an old, rickety, uninhabited house that was made for scares. Sentence3: The house was scary in itself. Sentence4: The scariest part was at the end. 
 (A) A witch jumped out and gave me the fright of my life. (B) They were having a Christmas party at the exit.

Sentence1: Sharon had kept a bag of unknown seeds for Years. Sentence2: She decided one day to plant the seeds. Sentence3: Sharon put them in planters, believing they would be small plants. Sentence4: Sharon couldn't have been more wrong in her assumption! 
 (A) She cracked open a beer and took a swig. (B) They ended up being huge plants.

Sentence1: Keri was babysitting her niece on a weekday. Sentence2: She needed to put her to sleep early. Sentence3: Unfortunately the niece had too much energy. Sentence4: Keri convinced her to do exercises with her. 
 (A) Then Keri took the child for  a  walk  to tire her out. (B) Keri convinced the waiter that he had overcharged  her.

Sentence1: John and Sue often kissed at school in between classes. Sentence2: They were told not to do it but they did anyway. Sentence3: One day the principal caught the two kissing. Sentence4: They were both suspended for a week. 
 (A) Their parents jointly threw them a huge party to celebrate. (B) They both learned their lesson and no longer kissed in school.

Sentence1: The girls went to a bar. Sentence2: They opened a tab. Sentence3: They had a few drinks. Sentence4: They finally decided to close their tab. 
 (A) They went home talking about their night. (B) They got into the plane.
